'''Socialist Worker ''' (SW) was a [[socialist]] organisation based in [[New Zealand|Aotearoa/New Zealand]].
SW evolved out of the group known as the [[Socialist Workers Organization (New Zealand)|Socialist Workers Organization]], the successor organisation of the [[Communist Party of New Zealand]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} It had two main branches in [[Auckland]] and [[Wellington]], but activists in most other cities in NZ.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} Recently,{{When|date=May 2011}} it began to grow modestly through work done in workers' organisations such as the [[Solidarity Union]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.solidarityunion.com | title=What is Solidarity Union, and what does it do? | publisher=Solidarity | accessdate=24 May 2011 }}</ref> [[Unite Union]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.unite.org.nz | title=Home | publisher=Unite | accessdate=24 May 2011 }}</ref> the Climate Change Coalition [[Climaction]],<ref>[http://www.climaction.org.nz]</ref>{{dead link|date=May 2011}} the [[anti-war]] movement and the Venezuela Aotearoa Solidarity Team.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.vastnz.blogspot.com | title=Home | publisher=Venezuela Aotearoa Solidarity Team | accessdate=24 May 2011 }}</ref>
Many of its key activists were involved in the [[Residents Action Movement]],{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} which polled over 87,000 votes in the 2004 [[Auckland Regional Council]] elections.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}}
It published a quarterly themed journal called ''[[UNITY]]'', and its activists contributed to the monthly ''[[Workers' Charter]]'' paper.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} It also had a regularly updated blog called ''UnityAotearoa''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://unityaotearoa.blogspot.com | title=Home | publisher=Unity | accessdate=24 May 2011 }}</ref>
SW's national conference in February 2007 adopted a new ten point "Where We Stand" programme.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://unityaotearoa.blogspot.com/2007/03/where-we-stand-socialist-workers-ten.html | title=WHERE WE STAND: Socialist Worker's ten-point programme | publisher=Unity | accessdate=24 May 2011 }}</ref>
SW was part of the [[International Socialist Tendency]] (IST). On May 1 2007, it presented a [[May Day]] Statement to the IST, calling for a positive engagement with the [[Venezuelan Revolution]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://unityaotearoa.blogspot.com/2007/05/may-day-statement-by-central-committee.html | title=May Day statement by central committee of Socialist Worker-New Zealand | publisher=Unity | accessdate=24 May 2011 }}</ref>
A number of SW members split from the organisation in 2008 to form [[Socialist Aotearoa]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://workersparty.org.nz/resources/open-letter-to-socialist-aotearoa-may-2008/ | title=Open Letter to Socialist Aotearoa (May 2008) | publisher=Workers Party New Zealand | date=1 May 2008 | accessdate=6 September 2010 }}</ref>
SW voted to dissolve itself at its conference in January 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unityaotearoa.blogspot.co.nz/2012/01/resolution-of-2012-conference-of.html|date=29 January 2012|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/65UTlQFLu|archivedate=16 February 2012|title=Resolution of 2012 conference of Socialist Worker}}</ref> Its ex-members went on to participate in the EcoSocialist Network.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}}
